title: Metalinguistic Analysis
description: Grammatical structures for analyzing language itself

sections.title: Describing Grammatical Phenomena
sections.explanation: Structures for discussing language patterns and rules.

patterns.pattern: In X, Y functions as/serves as...
patterns.example: In this sentence, 'however' functions as a conjunctive adverb connecting contrasting clauses.
Academic writing is characterized by complex noun phrases and extensive nominalization.
The verb 'believe' licenses a that-clause complement but not a to-infinitive with most subjects.
The definite article triggers the presupposition that the referent exists and is identifiable.

sections.title: Semantic and Pragmatic Description
sections.explanation: Language for analyzing meaning and use.

patterns.structure: X entails Y / Y follows from X
patterns.example: 'John killed Mary' entails 'Mary died'—if the first is true, the second must be.
Saying 'It's getting late' may implicate that the speaker wants to leave.

patterns.structure: X presupposes Y / X carries the presupposition that Y
patterns.example: 'John regrets leaving' presupposes that John left.

patterns.structure: In uttering X, the speaker performs/accomplishes Y
patterns.example: In uttering 'I promise to come,' the speaker performs the act of promising.
Unlike English, Korean lacks articles and marks topic-comment structure explicitly.

patterns.pattern: X patterns with Y in that...
patterns.example: Japanese patterns with Korean in having SOV word order and agglutinative morphology.

patterns.pattern: The X construction in Language A corresponds to...
patterns.example: The passive construction in English corresponds to several distinct constructions in Japanese, including the adversative passive.
'Going to' has grammaticalized from a motion verb phrase into a future tense marker.
'Kind of' > 'kinda' represents a case of phonological reduction accompanying semantic bleaching.

patterns.pattern: The development from X to Y illustrates...
patterns.example: The development from full verb to auxiliary illustrates the unidirectionality of grammaticalization.

exercises.instruction: Describe the presupposition in this sentence
exercises.answer: The question presupposes that the addressee has an assignment and has been working on it. If no assignment exists, the question is infelicitous (presupposition failure).

exercises.utterance: A: How did John do on the exam? B: He passed.
exercises.answer: B implicates that John's performance was merely adequate—not excellent. If John had done well, B would have said so (Grice's maxim of quantity).
